text: Wonderful, and also a bit worrying/weird for someone with history as a disciplinary background since the field (like any I bet) can be resistant to change.

anchor: Service  the work involved in project management, organization, â€˜back-endâ€™ production
text: Wonderful - looking forward to the practical experience in this realm in a learning environment (as in, it's okay to make mistakes!)

anchor: This aspect of the course will be graded based on a self-assessment and final interview
text: Weird/Wonderful: I agree with Kristen in regards to the weirdness and difficulty of self-assessment but I think it also presents an opportunity to critically reflect on what we were able to achieve and to recognize our failures. In the context of this course I think it is a particularly wonderful exercise as we are all coming from different backgrounds and it will allow us to mark the progress we made as individuals.

anchor: This aspect of the course is graded exceptional / pass / fail.
text: Wonderful/worrying: As a student I occasionally find myself preoccupied with the grades that I might receive (as most of us are likely to do). I think this method of assessment will enable me, perhaps my colleagues as well, to push the boundaries of what we might normally attempt. This of course comes with the possibility of failure but ideally these (small) failures can inform our work and we can continue to work towards something meaningful.

anchor: a year long project to write and publish a textbook for the digital humanities
text: I find the scope of the project to be a good opportunity to explore the key concepts within the DH and to perhaps come to our own definition of what it means to be emerging scholars in the field. I agree with Victoria in that it should help us to come to grips with some of the core concepts as well as to recognize some of the challenges and opportunities it presents.

anchor: Pseudonyms are ok
text: I have yet to decide how I feel about using a pseudonym: it makes me a tad worried that I have to contemplate it, but at the same time it is weird to be so attached to one's name and identity in such a public space, and lastly I think it's wonderful that the internet allows people the freedom to have these sorts of debates about privacy, academic culture, and the internet's place in all of this.

anchor: you may dismember, improve, remix, or rejig
text: Wonderful: emphasis on a collective knowledge and resources is always reassuring.

anchor: his aspect of the course will be graded based on a self-assessment and final interview.
text: Self-assessment is wonderful! Especially if coupled with some constructive criticism so I can learn to take pride in what I do right and learn from mistakes.

anchor: This aspect of the course is graded exceptional / pass / fail.
text: Could be weird or worrisome but as someone taking another simply pass/fail course I like the exceptional option and honestly collegiality is a hard to define and judge thing, therefore I agree that grading it can be nebulous at times.

anchor: the practices of thinking with rather than reflexively against both the people and the materials with which we work,
text: Super wonderful! Academia can be too much about disproving what someone has said or "putting your own spin" on things when perfectly sound work has been done already: I say harness that!

anchor: a year long project to write and publish a textbook for the digital humanities
text: I feel that as someone brand new to the field and learning it as I go it will be useful to write a textbook, where I can record my triumphs and what I am sure will be many failures. It will be interesting to see how my views on what the best way to present a textbook for DH changes as the year goes on.

anchor: The content, organization, and production of this textbook, and the management of this project, will be up to all of you
text: Wonderful: I think it's important for students to self-manage a project with direction from a professor instead of having to follow set guidelines. It allows us to experiment, to fail, to learn, and to succeed. Learning project management now will benefit those who end up in a job in that field and will help those already in the field grow.

anchor: d exceptional / pass / fail.
text: I must admit I share both Kirsten and Professor Graham's view on the grading of this course, as both weird and worrisome, however, I think it can also be wonderful. As someone who strives to always achieve the best grade possible ( as I am sure most of us do) I think not having a typical grading system enables us a great opportunity to focus on learning the material, and as Professor Graham has mentioned in this course, the  ability to fail and to learn from our failures.

anchor: publish a textbook
text: Worrying: As someone with very little knowledge about DH, I find it worrisome that we are tasked with providing a core understand of the subject to undergrads. That being said, once I've had more interaction with the subject I may feel differently. I am excited about this assignment; I am just worried that I have a narrow understanding of the subject right now.

anchor: a year long project to write and publish a textbook for the digital humanities,
text: I think this will be an enriching experience that enables us to write a textbook that is truly accessible to students; given that most of us are new to the world of DH, I think it will allow us to provide a perspective, while learning it ourselves, that takes into account the challenges that all newcomers in the Digital Humanities will have to overcome.
I love being at the interstices! That said, we have to learn how to bring this all back and make it safe for consumption in our own departments and disciplinary homes...

I know that teaching high school was the single hardest thing I've ever done, and it provided me with *ample* opportunities to reflect on what wasn't working. It wasn't until I started traveling with my students, as it were, rather than talking at them, that things started to click...

I have often found that I will think that I understand what's going on, and then have an absolutely disastrous encounter with it when I turn around to teach it. I wish I could teach it first before I actually get into a class... which is one reason why I turned to writing tutorials.

anchor: wonder aloud about how your discipline and dh might engage in the kind of generous thinking
text: Wonderful: I think this is something that all sectors/disciplines should engage in to an extent. I'd love to see more collaboration on how together we can improve processes and coordinate efforts.

And perhaps also worrying, eh? For my part, I think a lot of what I want to teach you ultimately becomes about habits and practice. If I gave numeric or letter grades, I think it'd take the focus off cultivating these habits of thought.

anchor: the practices of thinking with rather than reflexively against both the people and the materials with which we work
text: Wonderful: Based on my own experience teaching grade eleven english I find the collaborative approach to learning and writing to be beneficial for all members involved. The exchange of knowledge and sharing of skill sets creates new opportunities that otherwise might not have presented themselves. I think collegiality and generous thinking will be key to the success of the  DH-X Project.

anchor: This aspect of the course will be graded based on a self-assessment and final interview.
text: Weird: I always found this form of assessment to be difficult perhaps because of the difficulty of trying to remain modest while not "selling yourself short". However, I believe it is an important method of self discovery.

anchor: We will then pull these materials together into a textbook, which we will publish.
text: Wonderful.

anchor: Teaching writing and testing the exercises and tutorials within the textbook
text: Wonderful: to get the opportunity to teach and test exercises allows us to take on two roles which will expand our comprehension of the subject while ensuring that we are imparting the knowledge we intend to.

anchor: exceptional / pass / fail.

anchor: drawing the connections with other bodies of thought or artefacts
text: Wonderful: It's great to have the opportunity to engage with the ideas of others, many from other disciplines, which will broaden understanding and hopefully allow for a new perspective on information.

anchor: A failure shared is not a failure.
text: Is it that it's not a failure, or does it become a distributed learning opportunity? I get what you're saying with the headline, it just takes some thinking.

anchor: Why did it fail? It was a combination of at least four distinct problems (GRAHAM CITATION):  poor record keeping of the installation process of the various technologies that made it work computers talk to other computers to persuade them to do things. In this case, one computer injected malicious code into the technologies Graham was using to map the stories Graham ignored security warnings from the main platformâ€™s maintainers Backups and versioning: there were none.
text: This suggests that the project failed because of the choice in technology used though. If so, then would a lack of initial comparative analysis, and proper cost-benefit analysis not have been the root cause rather than the symptoms in these 4 steps?   I.e. Had you chosen a system that was more in line with your expertise, and that had some baked in security automation, would the project have failed if it was not hacked?   Or to look at it even another way, was the intent of the project to build an unhackable site or to collect stories?   This is an important distinction to make here methinks.

anchor: The earliest use of the â€˜fail betterâ€™ idea that we have found outside the world of literature and criticism seems to occur during the first tech boom, where it turns up in everything from diet books to learning to play jazz, to technology is in The Quest for a Unified Theory of Information
text: I disagree here. I think this concept actually stemmed from the Toyota production method in the 1930's (which was an interpretation of Henry Ford's method from the turn of the century) that eventually became known as lean, in which failure was seen as learning, and a way to not carry waste forward, but instead learn from errors in production and engage in a methodology of continuous improvement.  See: [History of Lean](https://www.lean.org/WhatsLean/History.cfm)

text: Wonderful: The opportunity to add to potential subjects is great.

anchor: I would like to meet with you individually before we meet as a group.
text: Wonderful: I appreciate the fact that you are taking the time to meet with each student. I have had some professors do this before and it worked really well.
I think it is interesting to look at the way that knowledge is socially constructed and that the manner it is constructed differs based on the discipline.
I think it is significant that you bring up the historical background as key to comprehending an idea. It is interesting to look at the evolution of a concept because it gives a broader vision.

anchor: Iâ€™m loathe to define DH
text: I love that DH is such a developing field that it resists definition. I find that although a tad worrisome in that it can be confusing, it also gives me the freedom to examine what I think DH is and to explore whatever winds up interesting me most about it.

anchor: tools
text: Wonderful: I think this is a valuable angle to explore as we dive further into the digital humanities, as I am sure that these new tools will come to alter our methodology within our respective programs and beyond.

I agree with Kirsten, definitions are useful in understanding an idea but they are always shifting, which is probably the case with DH as it is an emerging field. Therefore, I also find it helpful to understand the historical background of the word/concept and how it has changed throughout time. This give an idea of how the field of study has evolved over the years and enabling the opportunity to explore where it might be going.
There is a tendency to imagine that stuff is just 'out there' (thank you, Mulder), and this has to be resisted.
Reminds me of structuration theory, too. Giddens, etc.

Riffing from that point (the idea of sharing), take a look at Caulfied's thoughts on the 'Theology of the Attention Economy' https://hapgood.us/2017/09/05/students-as-creators-and-the-capitalist-impulse/

anchor: what our tools do to us
text: Wonderful/Worrying: Think of all the news articles posted that include the "public" perspective from twitter and the impact of technology use on access to news media. Local news is unstable, at least in Canada. How will that impact our identities as we see a more national picture? The PCH recently did a consultation about Canadian content in a digital world. The digital space is both making it easier and harder for us to define ourselves and share movies/art/music with others.

I always found the discussion of the potential impact of linguistic structures on how people see the world and express themselves in different cultures and contexts captivating. As well as the impact of social/political events on language shifts. It really is circular.
Give this a whirl: http://whatisdigitalhumanities.com/

anchor: There is no such thing as â€˜dataâ€™. There are only â€˜captaâ€™.
text: Wonderful: I find this to be refreshing as it acknowledges the constructed nature of knowledge as well as the ideology or bias that can be present in representations of information.

anchor: Archaeology teaches us that our things help make usÂ us as much as we make our things. What kind of a world are we building?
text: Wonderful: When I studied English and Applied Linguistics as an undergraduate, I was often drawn to the notion that the language we use is a circular device both created by society while also helping to shape society. I feel this is very similar in that language too is a tool. This is worrying too though because it provides humanity with a lot of perhaps unintentional agency in determining what world we are building and there is always the potential that it is not a good one.

anchor: â€™m loathe to define DH.
text: I find that definitions are very useful in creating a core idea of what something is. In fact, the dictionary is often where I first go to broaden my comprehension of an idea. However, definitions are constantly shifting and it is difficult to create an all encompassing description of something so broad and changing.

anchor: â€œthe myth of the English major barista,â€ù
text: Wonderful: this article was an interesting and a reassuring read as an English major.

anchor: as the belief that such skills are a luxury in the current economic environment persists
text: Worrying: While I understand the argument the author is intending to make, I think that the skills we develop (from a first hand experience) are in fact a luxury that many people don't have. The ability to write (clearly, without mistakes) and to think critically, is something I've seen people in other areas of study struggle with because they did not have he same type of education with the same elements stressed, as a humanity major has.

anchor: doing more of that work in conversation with the public
text: Wonderful: I think this is an interesting premise. There is always this pressure to be perfect and to show only final work. In having these conversations, we end up sharing our processes, our lessons learned, our practices of which others can benefit in for their own work. Further, this can spark interest and discussions, which can help drive research and thought.

anchor: Again, this is not to suggest that scholars must abandon critique or the social commitments that underwrite it, particularly in favor of an approach that might be more, as our students have it, â€œrelatable.â€ù
text: This is actually a pet-peeve of mine, when you get some egg-head individual trying to hide behind verbose explanations of what he/she does, as a way of trying to imbue their research with a mystique of importance, rather than trying to communicate its value in more approachable ways. It's as if they don't think through the "so what?" That should invariably follow academic statements.  In this way, we can engage more people and make them more conversant in the bigger issues in culture and society.
